case_vignette: A 57-year-old man is brought to the physician for worsening mental status over the past 2 months. His wife reports he was initially experiencing lapses in memory and over the past 3 weeks he has begun having difficulties performing activities of daily living. Yesterday, he became lost heading to the post office down the street. He has hypertension treated with lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is alert but verbally uncommunicative. Muscle strength is normal. Reflexes are 2+ in bilateral upper and lower extremities. He has diffuse involuntary muscle jerking that can be provoked by loud noises. Mental status examination shows a blunt affect. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of glucose, creatine, and electrolytes are within the reference range.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having memory lapses and trouble doing everyday things, and just yesterday, I got lost going to the post office on my street.
Have you noticed any changes in your mood or behavior recently?
Yes, my mood seems to be flat lately.
Have you had any recent head injuries or surgeries?
No, I haven't had any head injuries or surgeries recently.

I haven't had any seizures or blackouts, but I do have involuntary muscle jerking that gets worse with loud noises.
Have you been taking any medications for any medical conditions?
Yes, I take medication for high blood pressure.

No changes in my vision or hearing have been mentioned.
Have you noticed any changes in your sleep patterns or appetite?
There's no mention of changes in my sleep patterns or appetite.
Have you noticed any changes in your speech or language abilities?
I've become verbally uncommunicative recently.
Have you noticed any changes in your coordination or balance?
No, my muscle strength is normal and there've been no mentions of coordination or balance issues.
Have you noticed any changes in your reflexes or reaction times?
My reflexes are active and the same in both my arms and legs.
Have you noticed any changes in your gait or posture?
There haven't been any mentions of changes in my gait or posture.
Have you noticed any changes in your facial expressions or movements?
My facial expressions seem to be less expressive than usual.
Have you noticed any changes in your swallowing or breathing?
There have been no mentions of changes in my swallowing or breathing.
Have you noticed any changes in your heart rate or blood pressure?
My vital signs are within normal limits.
Have you noticed any changes in your skin or hair?

trial_0.summarized_conversation: The patient has been experiencing memory lapses and trouble with everyday tasks, and recently got lost on the way to the post office. The patient reports a flat mood and involuntary muscle jerking that worsens with loud noises. The patient takes medication for high blood pressure and has not had any head injuries or surgeries. There have been no seizures or blackouts, and no changes in vision, hearing, sleep patterns, or appetite. The patient has become verbally uncommunicative, and facial expressions seem less expressive than usual. There have been no changes in muscle strength, coordination, balance, gait, posture, swallowing, or breathing. The patient's reflexes are active and the same in both arms and legs, and vital signs are within normal limits.
